description: From phthal(ic) +â€Ž -ate, short for obsolete naphthalic acid, from naphthalene.

entries.meaning: (organic chemistry) Any salt or ester of a phthalic acid.
examples: Researchers investigating levels of phthalates in the human body, which have been linked to asthma, breast cancer, type 2 diabetes and fertility issues in the past few years, were found to be nearly 35% higher in participants who had eaten out the previous day compared with those who stayed at home.
